item.title: GSoC week 8: Reservoir Computing with Cellular Automata Part 2
item.description: Continuing the work started last week we are going to further explore the capabilities of Reservoir Computing using Cellular Automata (CA) as the reservoir.

item.title: GSoC week 7: Reservoir Computing with Cellular Automata Part 1
item.description: In the past few years a new framework based on the concept of Reservoir Computing has been proposed: the Cellular Automata based Reservoir Computer (ReCA) [1].

item.title: GSoC week 6: minimum complexity echo state network
item.description: Up until now we used reservoir generated mainly through a random process, and this approach requires a lot of fine parameter tuning.

item.title: Data-driven prediction of chaotic systems: comparison of Echo State Network variations
item.description: This post is meant to be a high level comparison of different variations of the Echo State Network (ESN) model, implemented in the first month of Google Summer of Code.

item.title: GSoC week 4: SVD-based Reservoir
item.description: The standard construction of the reservoir matrix \( \textbf{W} \) for Echo State Networks (ESN) is based on initializing \( \textbf{W} \) using specific schemes, usually generating random numbers and then rescaling it to make sure that the spectral radius is less or equal to a chosen number.

item.title: GSoC week 3: Echo State Gaussian Processes
item.description: Continuing to leverage similarities between Reservoir Computing models and Kernel machines, this week’s implementation merges the Bayesian approach of Gaussian Process Regression (GPR) to the Echo State Networks (ESN).

item.title: GSoC week 2: Support Vector Regression in Echo State Networks
item.description: The second week of the Google Summer of Code project with ReservoirComputing.

item.title: GSoC week 1: lasso, Elastic Net and Huber loss
item.description: The first week tackled the implementation of different kind of linear regression for the creation of the last layer in the Echo State Network.

item.title: Contact
item.description: The most reliable way to contact me is to write at one of the following:

item.title: A brief introduction to Reservoir Computing
item.description: This post is meant to work as an high level introduction to the concept of Reservoir Computing, using the Julia package ReservoirComputing.

item.title: About
item.description: Hello there! I am Francesco Martinuzzi, a Physics student in the last year of a computational Condensed Matter master degree in Trieste.
